intro: Haplosphaera phaea, commonly known as the common liverwort, is a non-vascular plant belonging to the family Pottiaceae. It is a small, mat-forming plant that typically grows in moist, shaded environments such as forest floors or rocky crevices. The plant has a thalloid structure, consisting of a flat, leaf-like body that is covered in small, scale-like structures called rhizoids. It lacks true leaves, stems, and roots, and instead absorbs water and nutrients directly through its thallus. Haplosphaera phaea plays an important role in soil stabilization and as a pioneer species in ecological succession.
